values.description:
* Generate widgets for repeated:
    * nested messages
    * fields
* Update repeated fields and remove/add instances as needed
* Set/Get property values by name
* Get property count

![repeatscene.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/3546174720-repeatscene.gif)

![repeatlaser.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/764839480-repeatlaser.gif)


* There are no tests for repeated enums and repeated booleans because we don't have any messages like this on `ign-msgs`. I suppose we could create new messages just for the test, but at this point I think it's not worth the trouble.

    • nested messages

  • There are no tests for repeated enums and repeated booleans because we don't have any messages like this on ign-msgs. I suppose we could create new messages just for the test, but at this point I think it's not worth the trouble.

values.description:
## Update

After much debugging, I found out that the container and pills change their global position after the 1st mouse move, but only locally, not on Jenkins. I tried:

* putting the container inside a main window
* showing it on different parts of the test
* Changing the pill's sizes
* Adding text to the pills

But nothing made the behaviour consistent between local and Jenkins. So I found a compromise, if the container moves (local behaviour), we expect the test to pass, otherwise (Jenkins behaviour), we skip it.
values.title: Disable VariablePill test on Jenkins

summary.raw:
## Update

After much debugging, I found out that the container and pills change their global position after the 1st mouse move, but only locally, not on Jenkins. I tried:

* putting the container inside a main window
* showing it on different parts of the test
* Changing the pill's sizes
* Adding text to the pills

But nothing made the behaviour consistent between local and Jenkins. So I found a compromise, if the container moves (local behaviour), we expect the test to pass, otherwise (Jenkins behaviour), we skip it.
summary.html:
Update

After much debugging, I found out that the container and pills change their global position after the 1st mouse move, but only locally, not on Jenkins. I tried:

  • putting the container inside a main window
  • showing it on different parts of the test
  • Changing the pill's sizes
  • Adding text to the pills

But nothing made the behaviour consistent between local and Jenkins. So I found a compromise, if the container moves (local behaviour), we expect the test to pass, otherwise (Jenkins behaviour), we skip it.

values.description:
This is the start of bringing rendering to Ignition GUI.

### Scene3D

The `Scene3D` plugin offers an interactive view into a 3D scene. It may create an empty scene or add a new "user camera" to an existing scene. 

The idea is to keep it very basic so it can be reused for many use cases. All it offers is:

* Simple mouse controls (We will be improving native mouse controls on ign-rendering so the current implementation is very naive just to have something working. I didn't even bother writing tests for it yet)

* Configuration of scene properties at startup, such as background color

* Configuration of camera properties at startup (only pose for now)

The idea is not to add any more functionality to this plugin. Instead, other plugins can be used to populate and manage the scene. 

We take advantage of the fact that the render engine on ign-rendering is a singleton so that other plugins on the same process can directly access its scenes. The `Grid3D` plugin offers an example.

### Grid3D

This is an example of a plugin which connects to a scene previously created on a `Scene3D` plugin and  creates / reads / updates / removes resources from it.

* It can insert grids:

    * at startup according to the config file
    * via the GUI

* It can inspect properties, edit and delete grids through the UI

* The refresh button is useful to reload the list of grids in case grids have been deleted / created by others

* Added a `delete_later` attribute so any plugin can choose to close itself

This is intended as an example, I can imagine we add similar plugins for lights, geometries, etc.

### Demo

Run the demo:

    ign gui -c ../examples/config/scene3d.config

![gridpr.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/511624492-gridpr.gif)

I encourage reviewers to:

* Play with different scene / grid configuration files
* Add / remove plugins
* Try out all the buttons on the GUI

### Future (closely related) work

* Save updated properties on config file when plugins are saved

* Add a separate plugin to manage scene properties via the GUI, the same way we can manage grids

* How to save a "delete-later" plugin?
values.title: Rendering plugins: Scene3D and Grid3D

summary.raw:
This is the start of bringing rendering to Ignition GUI.

### Scene3D

The `Scene3D` plugin offers an interactive view into a 3D scene. It may create an empty scene or add a new "user camera" to an existing scene. 

The idea is to keep it very basic so it can be reused for many use cases. All it offers is:

* Simple mouse controls (We will be improving native mouse controls on ign-rendering so the current implementation is very naive just to have something working. I didn't even bother writing tests for it yet)

* Configuration of scene properties at startup, such as background color

* Configuration of camera properties at startup (only pose for now)

The idea is not to add any more functionality to this plugin. Instead, other plugins can be used to populate and manage the scene. 

We take advantage of the fact that the render engine on ign-rendering is a singleton so that other plugins on the same process can directly access its scenes. The `Grid3D` plugin offers an example.

### Grid3D

This is an example of a plugin which connects to a scene previously created on a `Scene3D` plugin and  creates / reads / updates / removes resources from it.

* It can insert grids:

    * at startup according to the config file
    * via the GUI

* It can inspect properties, edit and delete grids through the UI

* The refresh button is useful to reload the list of grids in case grids have been deleted / created by others

* Added a `delete_later` attribute so any plugin can choose to close itself

This is intended as an example, I can imagine we add similar plugins for lights, geometries, etc.

### Demo

Run the demo:

    ign gui -c ../examples/config/scene3d.config

![gridpr.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/511624492-gridpr.gif)

I encourage reviewers to:

* Play with different scene / grid configuration files
* Add / remove plugins
* Try out all the buttons on the GUI

### Future (closely related) work

* Save updated properties on config file when plugins are saved

* Add a separate plugin to manage scene properties via the GUI, the same way we can manage grids

* How to save a "delete-later" plugin?
summary.html:
This is the start of bringing rendering to Ignition GUI.

Scene3D

The Scene3D plugin offers an interactive view into a 3D scene. It may create an empty scene or add a new "user camera" to an existing scene.

The idea is to keep it very basic so it can be reused for many use cases. All it offers is:

  • Simple mouse controls (We will be improving native mouse controls on ign-rendering so the current implementation is very naive just to have something working. I didn't even bother writing tests for it yet)

  • Configuration of scene properties at startup, such as background color

  • Configuration of camera properties at startup (only pose for now)

The idea is not to add any more functionality to this plugin. Instead, other plugins can be used to populate and manage the scene.

We take advantage of the fact that the render engine on ign-rendering is a singleton so that other plugins on the same process can directly access its scenes. The Grid3D plugin offers an example.

Grid3D

This is an example of a plugin which connects to a scene previously created on a Scene3D plugin and creates / reads / updates / removes resources from it.

  • It can insert grids:

    • at startup according to the config file
    • via the GUI

  • It can inspect properties, edit and delete grids through the UI

  • The refresh button is useful to reload the list of grids in case grids have been deleted / created by others

  • Added a delete_later attribute so any plugin can choose to close itself

This is intended as an example, I can imagine we add similar plugins for lights, geometries, etc.

Demo

Run the demo:

ign gui -c ../examples/config/scene3d.config

I encourage reviewers to:

  • Play with different scene / grid configuration files
  • Add / remove plugins
  • Try out all the buttons on the GUI

Future (closely related) work

  • Save updated properties on config file when plugins are saved

  • Add a separate plugin to manage scene properties via the GUI, the same way we can manage grids

  • How to save a "delete-later" plugin?

values.description:
This needs [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/73) Ignition Common pull request.

Related to issue #11

## Context

Ignition common's plugin framework is going through changes to make sure shared libraries are properly unloaded when they are no longer being used. To achieve this, the plugin framework needs to keep ownership of the interfaces it provides. To that end, it only makes shared pointers available, and when those pointers are released, the library is unloaded.

## Problem

Qt likes to keep ownership of its objects. So as long as our plugin interfaces are `QObject`s, we need to share the interface's  underlying raw pointer.

## The "right" solution

@mxgrey has a lot of detailed insights on issue #11, and proposed a solution which involves having the interface not be a `QObject`, but a factory of `QObject`s.

While the proposed solution sounds robust, it would require changes on ign-common and ign-gui. And, arguably more importantly, on user code.

So I propose we keep the factory approach in mind, but for now implement a less invasive solution just to make sure we don't block ign-common's progress. Once the plugin framework is more complete, we can revisit this and see if the factory approach still makes sense.

## The current solution

The approach on this pull request is based on the following goals:

1. Never let Qt delete our plugins

    > This is achieved by intercepting close/reject events on plugin parents (`Dock`s and `Dialog`s) and removing the plugin from the parent before the parent dies.

2. Detect when Qt would like to delete the plugin and release our `shared_ptr` so ign-common can unload the library if needed

    > This is done by emitting a `Closing` signal
values.title: Use Ignition Common's new plugin framework

Related to issue #11

## Context

Ignition common's plugin framework is going through changes to make sure shared libraries are properly unloaded when they are no longer being used. To achieve this, the plugin framework needs to keep ownership of the interfaces it provides. To that end, it only makes shared pointers available, and when those pointers are released, the library is unloaded.

## Problem

Qt likes to keep ownership of its objects. So as long as our plugin interfaces are `QObject`s, we need to share the interface's  underlying raw pointer.

## The "right" solution

@mxgrey has a lot of detailed insights on issue #11, and proposed a solution which involves having the interface not be a `QObject`, but a factory of `QObject`s.

While the proposed solution sounds robust, it would require changes on ign-common and ign-gui. And, arguably more importantly, on user code.

So I propose we keep the factory approach in mind, but for now implement a less invasive solution just to make sure we don't block ign-common's progress. Once the plugin framework is more complete, we can revisit this and see if the factory approach still makes sense.

## The current solution

The approach on this pull request is based on the following goals:

1. Never let Qt delete our plugins

    > This is achieved by intercepting close/reject events on plugin parents (`Dock`s and `Dialog`s) and removing the plugin from the parent before the parent dies.

2. Detect when Qt would like to delete the plugin and release our `shared_ptr` so ign-common can unload the library if needed

    > This is done by emitting a `Closing` signal
summary.html:
This needs this Ignition Common pull request.

Related to issue #11

Context

Ignition common's plugin framework is going through changes to make sure shared libraries are properly unloaded when they are no longer being used. To achieve this, the plugin framework needs to keep ownership of the interfaces it provides. To that end, it only makes shared pointers available, and when those pointers are released, the library is unloaded.

Problem

Qt likes to keep ownership of its objects. So as long as our plugin interfaces are QObjects, we need to share the interface's underlying raw pointer.

The "right" solution

@mxgrey has a lot of detailed insights on issue #11, and proposed a solution which involves having the interface not be a QObject, but a factory of QObjects.

While the proposed solution sounds robust, it would require changes on ign-common and ign-gui. And, arguably more importantly, on user code.

So I propose we keep the factory approach in mind, but for now implement a less invasive solution just to make sure we don't block ign-common's progress. Once the plugin framework is more complete, we can revisit this and see if the factory approach still makes sense.

The current solution

The approach on this pull request is based on the following goals:

  1. Never let Qt delete our plugins

    This is achieved by intercepting close/reject events on plugin parents (Docks and Dialogs) and removing the plugin from the parent before the parent dies.

  2. Detect when Qt would like to delete the plugin and release our shared_ptr so ign-common can unload the library if needed

    This is done by emitting a Closing signal

values.description:
* Remove `Plot` prefix from classes in the `plot` namespace
* Disable Ignition GUI's context menu for the Plot plugin so that the right-drag zoom works
* Added more documentation
* Removed some unnecessary `ignition::`s
* Added some `override`s
* Added tests for `IncrementalPlot` - `Update` and `Magnify`
* Removed some member variables which didn't need to be kept as members
* Made the tracker enabled by default since we have no way to turn it on right now
* Added a couple of curves to the plugin so we can manually test things

![plotting.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/111703057-plotting.gif)
values.title: Tweaks to pull request #59

values.description:
This builds on top of ~~pull request #62~~

I call it advanced settings because all the plugin is providing is a direct interface to the parameters exposed by Ignition Rendering. A more intuitive user interface would involve more mouse interaction, like right-clicking the node to be followed through the eyes of the camera.

There are detailed instructions on the animated box example plugin README.

![tracking.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/2345997651-tracking.gif)
values.title: Camera tracking - advanced settings

values.description:
Addresses issue #13, now if no argument is passed to `-v`, it defaults to maximum verbosity.

I tried for a while to write a test for this, but it was taking me too long to find a non-blocking way to implement `custom_exec_str`. Maybe someone has a nice idea how to do this.

These ones are left: ~~~ :1: warning: documented symbol `T abs' was not declared or defined. :1: warning: documented symbol `T abs' was not declared or defined. :1: warning: documented symbol `T abs' was not declared or defined. :1: warning: documented symbol `T abs' was not declared or defined. ~~~ No idea where it's coming from `warning: Include graph for 'qt.h' not generated, too many nodes. Consider increasing DOT_GRAPH_MAX_NODES.` I'll leave this one for now ~~~ /home/louise/code/ign-gui/README.md:4: warning: Unexpected html tag found within context /home/louise/code/ign-gui/README.md:5: warning: Unexpected html tag found within context /home/louise/code/ign-gui/README.md:6: warning: Unexpected html tag found within context /home/louise/code/ign-gui/README.md:7: warning: Unexpected html tag found within context ~~~ These are coming from the badges, apparently doxygen is [not good](http://doxygen.10944.n7.nabble.com/Warning-Unexpected-html-tag-lt-img-gt-found-within-lt-a-href-gt-context-td7216.html) with image links

values.description:
See pull request #81

After removing all the Gazebo-specific code from the plot manager, all that was left was the `topicCurve` member variable.

This PR removes the Manager completely. Besides serving only as a wrapper for the topic curve handler, the singleton approach feels incompatible Ignition GUI's plugin structure.

:warning: There is one change in behaviour though. 

With a single `topicCurve`, all canvases shared the same start time. Now, each canvas starts from a different zero. 

I'm not sure how this currently affects downstream applications. If we need them to share the time, we could make the variable static for example.

From my point of view, the time is already broken until we tackle issue #18.
values.title: Plot: Remove manager

summary.raw:
See pull request #81

After removing all the Gazebo-specific code from the plot manager, all that was left was the `topicCurve` member variable.

This PR removes the Manager completely. Besides serving only as a wrapper for the topic curve handler, the singleton approach feels incompatible Ignition GUI's plugin structure.

:warning: There is one change in behaviour though. 

With a single `topicCurve`, all canvases shared the same start time. Now, each canvas starts from a different zero. 

I'm not sure how this currently affects downstream applications. If we need them to share the time, we could make the variable static for example.

From my point of view, the time is already broken until we tackle issue #18.
summary.html:
See pull request #81

After removing all the Gazebo-specific code from the plot manager, all that was left was the topicCurve member variable.

This PR removes the Manager completely. Besides serving only as a wrapper for the topic curve handler, the singleton approach feels incompatible Ignition GUI's plugin structure.

There is one change in behaviour though.

With a single topicCurve, all canvases shared the same start time. Now, each canvas starts from a different zero.

I'm not sure how this currently affects downstream applications. If we need them to share the time, we could make the variable static for example.

From my point of view, the time is already broken until we tackle issue #18.

values.description:
When porting code from Gazebo to Ignition GUI, it is important to remove hardcoded styles so consumers of the library can customize their styles without recompiling the plugins.

While porting the variable pills from Gazebo on pull request #49, we removed the hardcoded styles but left them incomplete. This pull request uses [dynamic properties](https://wiki.qt.io/Dynamic_Properties_and_Stylesheets) to keep all the styling in a QSS file.

I also simplified the nested layouts and frames so it is easier to understand what's going on.

![pillsstyle.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/3992135982-pillsstyle.gif)
values.title: Dynamic stylesheet for VariablePill

While porting the variable pills from Gazebo on pull request #49, we removed the hardcoded styles but left them incomplete. This pull request uses dynamic properties to keep all the styling in a QSS file.

values.description: The subscription callback `OnWorldStatsMsg()` was calling `QMetaObject::invokeMethod(this, "ProcessMsg")` to update some QT widgets outside of the QT thread. This pull request changes the logic to emit a signal instead.
values.title: Fix issue with time plugin

summary.raw: The subscription callback `OnWorldStatsMsg()` was calling `QMetaObject::invokeMethod(this, "ProcessMsg")` to update some QT widgets outside of the QT thread. This pull request changes the logic to emit a signal instead.
summary.html: The subscription callback OnWorldStatsMsg() was calling QMetaObject::invokeMethod(this, "ProcessMsg") to update some QT widgets outside of the QT thread. This pull request changes the logic to emit a signal instead.

values.description:
This PR allows to drag fields from the scene tree widget into the plot widget. For now, I started with the `Pose3d` field.

You can test this by:

* Launching the topic interface example:

```
#!c++

  ign gui -c examples/config/topicInterface.config
```
* Increase the frequency to 1Hz and click `Publish`.
* Launch the plotting widget:

  
```
#!c++

ign gui -c examples/config/plot.config
```

* On the scene tree widget, expand `Model`, expand one of the three models received, expand `Pose`, and drag and drop any of the fields into the plotting widget. Note that these fields are initialized to 0, so nothing interesting should happen, but at least the plotting tool should start plotting the zeros.

Thanks to @iche033 and @chapulina for the help!
values.title: Drag fields from the scene tree widget into the plot widget

summary.raw:
This PR allows to drag fields from the scene tree widget into the plot widget. For now, I started with the `Pose3d` field.

You can test this by:

* Launching the topic interface example:

```
#!c++

  ign gui -c examples/config/topicInterface.config
```
* Increase the frequency to 1Hz and click `Publish`.
* Launch the plotting widget:

  
```
#!c++

ign gui -c examples/config/plot.config
```

* On the scene tree widget, expand `Model`, expand one of the three models received, expand `Pose`, and drag and drop any of the fields into the plotting widget. Note that these fields are initialized to 0, so nothing interesting should happen, but at least the plotting tool should start plotting the zeros.

Thanks to @iche033 and @chapulina for the help!
summary.html:
This PR allows to drag fields from the scene tree widget into the plot widget. For now, I started with the Pose3d field.

You can test this by:

  • Launching the topic interface example:
  ign gui -c examples/config/topicInterface.config
  • Increase the frequency to 1Hz and click Publish.
  • Launch the plotting widget:
ign gui -c examples/config/plot.config
  • On the scene tree widget, expand Model, expand one of the three models received, expand Pose, and drag and drop any of the fields into the plotting widget. Note that these fields are initialized to 0, so nothing interesting should happen, but at least the plotting tool should start plotting the zeros.

Thanks to @iche033 and @chapulina for the help!

values.description:
The `TopicCurve::UpdateCurve()` function was parsing the message looking for a `stamp` or `field` fields. If found, it assumed that the message was stamped and used the time contained in the message.

However I found that the we're stamping the messages with a `header` field, so this method needs to be updated.

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #93, which should be merged first. [Here's a better diff](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/branches/compare/plot_stamped_msgs%0Dscene_tree_plot#diff).
values.title: Receive stamped msgs for plotting

summary.raw:
The `TopicCurve::UpdateCurve()` function was parsing the message looking for a `stamp` or `field` fields. If found, it assumed that the message was stamped and used the time contained in the message.

However I found that the we're stamping the messages with a `header` field, so this method needs to be updated.

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #93, which should be merged first. [Here's a better diff](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/branches/compare/plot_stamped_msgs%0Dscene_tree_plot#diff).
summary.html:
The TopicCurve::UpdateCurve() function was parsing the message looking for a stamp or field fields. If found, it assumed that the message was stamped and used the time contained in the message.

However I found that the we're stamping the messages with a header field, so this method needs to be updated.

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #93, which should be merged first. Here's a better diff.

values.description:
This would be useful for me and matches what RViz does.

95% of the time when starting without a specific configuration you would like to re-start at the last open configuration. When you do want to start with a specific configuration you'll always load it.

More convenient than having to 'save configuration' all the time.
values.title: save configuration to the default location on exit

values.description:
To match ign-fuel-tools, see [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/44/command-line-verbosity-and-models-by-user/diff):

* No `-v`: defaults to errors only (1)
* `-v` without arg: defaults to errors, warnings and info (3)
values.title: Adjust command line verbosity

* `-v` without arg: defaults to errors, warnings and info (3)
